item.title: Zoox rolls outs custom robotaxi in San Francisco, Las Vegas
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description:
Zoox is testing its custom robotaxis, which are built without a steering wheel or pedals, on public roads in San Francisco and the Las Vegas Strip.  The rollout of the autonomous vehicles, which Zoox CTO Jesse Levinson first announced at TechCrunch Disrupt, is a public show of force from the Amazon-backed company. Federal regulations prohibit […]

item.title: Dapr graduates to become a CNCF top-level project
item.dc:creator: Frederic Lardinois
item.description:
Dapr, the Microsoft-incubated open source runtime for helping developers build secure and resilient distributed applications, has graduated from the Cloud Native Computing Foundation’s (CNCF) pool of incubating projects to become a top-level project at the same level of projects like Kubernetes, Prometheus, Istio, and Vitess. To graduate to this level, a project has to be […]

item.title: Snowflake hackers identified and charged with stealing 50 billion AT&T records
item.dc:creator: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
item.description:
The U.S. Department of justice indicted two hackers for breaking into the systems of AT&T and several other companies.

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Altos Ventures, an early backer of Coupang and Roblox, raises $500M fund
item.dc:creator: Tage Kene-Okafor
item.description:
Altos Ventures, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm that has backed the likes of Roblox, Coupang, PandaDoc and Quizlet, has secured $500 million for its latest fund, according to SEC filings. The firm has been around for almost three decades and this is its largest fund to date. Altos Ventures declined to comment on the […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Now anyone in LA can hail a Waymo robotaxi
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec
item.description:
Waymo has opened its robotaxi service to everyone in Los Angeles, sunsetting a waitlist that had grown to 300,000 people. The Alphabet-backed company said starting Tuesday anyone can download the Waymo One app to hail a ride in its service area, which is now about 80 square miles in Los Angeles County. Waymo has had […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Particle launches an AI news app to help publishers, instead of just stealing their work
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description:
The media industry today may not have a very favorable view of AI — a technology that’s already been used to replace reporters with AI-written copy, while other AI companies have scooped up journalists’ work to feed their chatbots’ data demands, but without returning traffic to the publisher as search engines once did. However, one […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: TikTok launches integration with Lemon8, as US ban looms
item.dc:creator: Aisha Malik
item.description:
Users will be able to directly access Lemon8, ByteDance’s newer social media app, with their TikTok account, the company announced Tuesday. ByteDance says the integration will make photo sharing more feasible, and give creators the ability to cross-share photo content between the apps. Lemon8 will remain a separate app, but the two platforms will share […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: French newspapers want social media platform X to pay for news reuse
item.dc:creator: Romain Dillet
item.description:
It’s rare when French newspapers team up and agree on something. But major publications, such as Le Monde, Le Figaro and Le Parisien have collectively decided to take legal action against X over neighboring rights, according to a statement sent to Reuters and the AFP. Under EU law, digital platforms are required to negotiate with […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: LocalStack raises $25M to help developers emulate and test cloud apps locally
item.dc:creator: Paul Sawers
item.description:
Knowing how your cloud application will behave in production usually requires significant development and testing in the environment in which it will be deployed, be that AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, or wherever. But this can be a resource-intensive endeavor, particularly with issues relating to latency (the time it takes to constantly send data) and the […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Bounce bags $19M to expand its traveler convenience network
item.dc:creator: Natasha Lomas
item.description:
Luggage storage as a vector for piling into convenience-based revenue opportunities in the business of global travel continues to put a spring in San Francisco-based Bounce‘s step. The startup has just tucked $19 million in Series B funding into its suitcase, with a plan to keep rolling revenue that’s grown 20x since its $12M Series […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: SUSE launches a cloud observability service
item.dc:creator: Frederic Lardinois
item.description:
Luxembourg-based SUSE has long offered various services around its various Linux- and cloud-centric infrastructure and security tools. Yet what the company didn’t really offer before was a more traditional SaaS product. That’s changing now with the early access launch of SUSE Cloud Observability, a fully managed observability platform designed for Rancher-managed multi-cloud Kubernetes clusters. Rancher, […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: This USB-C mouthpiece turns your phone into a musical instrument
item.dc:creator: Lauren Forristal
item.description:
Artinoise, the Italian startup behind re.corder — a smart device reimagining the traditional plastic recorder we all played in school — has introduced its latest product: Zefiro. The portable device, shaped like the mouthpiece of a recorder, can be plugged into any smartphone, tablet, or PC with a USB-C port, effectively transforming it into a […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Europe’s DMA forces Meta towards ‘less personalized ads’
item.dc:creator: Natasha Lomas
item.description:
Meta, under legal pressure in the European Union over a binary ‘pay us or consent to ad tracking’ choice it currently offers regional users of its social networks Facebook and Instagram, is changing how its regional ad business works again. Little wonder when compliance failure in this context risks fines of up to 10% of […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: NitroVolt is helping farmers make their own fertilizer using renewable power
item.dc:creator: Tim De Chant
item.description:
The majority of the world’s ammonia is produced using the 115-year-old Haber-Bosch process, which is heavily reliant on natural gas. NitroVolt could change that.

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Generative AI startup Writer raises $200M at a $1.9B valuation
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
Writer has raised $200 million at a $1.9 billion valuation to expand its enterprise-focused generative AI platform. The Series C round was co-led by Premji Invest, Radical Ventures and ICONIQ Growth, with participation from Salesforce Ventures, Adobe Ventures, B Capital, Citi Ventures, IBM Ventures and Workday Ventures. Writer CEO May Habib says the new cash, […]

item.title: ScaleOps aims to take the frustration out of cloud management
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
ScaleOps, an automated cloud management platform, has closed a $58 million Series B, bringing its total raised to $80 million.

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Amazon attempts to lure AI researchers with $110M in grants and credits
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
There’s an AI chip battle brewing among the major cloud vendors. Google’s Trillium, a custom chip for training and running AI models, recently entered preview, and Microsoft’s Maia is expected to follow in short order. Not to be outdone, Amazon Web Services has AI chips, too: Trainium, Inferentia, and Graviton. In an effort to draw […]

item.title: General Catalyst and Khosla Ventures back data mapping startup Lume
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description:
Data integration is a necessary part of many workflows from onboarding customer data to exercising payroll, but for many data sets the process is long and manual. Data is siloed into databases and SaaS applications that each keep the information in different formats, which makes it difficult to move information from one database to another. […]

item.title: How two brothers went from growing up on a sailboat to making underwater military vehicles
item.dc:creator: Margaux MacColl
item.description:
Vatn Systems founders Nelson and Freddie Mills spent their childhood cruising over turquoise waters, doing their homework on a sailboat off the coast of Caribbean islands. While their surroundings were idyllic, their vessel of choice was decidedly not. “The first boat I remember, I think our parents bought it for like five, ten grand,” Freddie […]

item.title: Apple’s geoblocks on media services in EU draw consumer protection ire
item.dc:creator: Natasha Lomas
item.description:
Apple’s pile of regulatory woes in the European Union has ticked up again: the iPhone maker is being accused of unlawfully discriminating against consumers by applying restrictions on how several of its media services can be accessed around the bloc. Consumer protection authorities in three EU Member States have been investigating the geoblocking measures (access […]
